Description: Fix bug where record rejected via find stayed in loading state
Description Abstract: Fix bug where record rejected via find stayed in loading state

Message: Fix bug where record rejected via find stayed in loading state
Description: store.getById(typeClass, id) is used inside the rejection handler of find to get the record and invoke the corresponding hooks. This is buggy since the record is not loaded yet into the store - a successful find would mark it as such - and hence the store.getById returned null. That's why the hooks are not called and the record stays in the loading state, having the isLoaded flag still being set to false. The fix is to reuse the record parameter, which is passed to the find method. By this, the hooks are invoked and the record is passed transitioned out of the loading state.
Message Abstract: Fix bug where record rejected via find stayed in loading state
Description Abstract: store.getById(typeClass, id) is used inside the rejection handler of find to get the record and invoke the corresponding hooks. This is buggy since the record is not loaded yet into the store - a successful find would mark it as such - and hence the store.getById returned null. That's why the hooks are not called and the record stays in the loading state, having the isLoaded flag still being set to false. The fix is to reuse the record parameter, which is passed to the find method. By this, the hooks are invoked and the record is passed transitioned out of the loading state.

Description: Remove logic for camelCase-ing error keys in ActiveModelAdapter
Description Abstract: Remove logic for camelCase-ing error keys in ActiveModelAdapter

Message: Remove logic for camelCase-ing error keys in ActiveModelAdapter
Description: Since c947e254ac6df93bd8b1b836e526fbd7b648f8ba the keys of the error object are camelCased in the adapter, which is actually a serializer concern. The JSONSerializer, from which the ActiveModelSerializer extends, does a normalization of the errors object in the extractErrors hook (see http://git.io/vJ0A6 & http://git.io/vJ0AS) and this hook gets called by the store when the adapter rejects (see http://git.io/vJ0AI), the camelCase can be removed from inside the adapter. A test for the correct normalization of the errors object is added to the ActiveModelSerializer test suite.
Message Abstract: Remove logic for camelCase-ing error keys in ActiveModelAdapter
Description Abstract: Since c947e254ac6df93bd8b1b836e526fbd7b648f8ba the keys of the error object are camelCased in the adapter, which is actually a serializer concern. The JSONSerializer, from which the ActiveModelSerializer extends, does a normalization of the errors object in the extractErrors hook (see link & link) and this hook gets called by the store when the adapter rejects (see link), the camelCase can be removed from inside the adapter. A test for the correct normalization of the errors object is added to the ActiveModelSerializer test suite.

Message: use typeKey and typeClass instead of using type inconsistently
Description: Before, we exchanged type and typeKey intermittently. Sometimes it was one or the other. This changes most usages of type to either typeKey or typeClass for internal consistency. The API docs were also changed to reflect this. The Store API docs have been changed to suggest using a string for a future patchset where we don't take factories to the store finder methods.

The Store API docs have been changed to suggest using a string for a future patchset where we don't take factories to the store finder methods.

Message: Use the correct interface for InvalidError
Description: Expects the error keys to be top-level: For Ember Data to correctly map errors to their corresponding properties on the model, Ember Data expects each error to be namespaced under a key that matches the property name.  return Ember.RSVP.reject(new DS.InvalidError({         title: ['Must be unique'],         content: ['Must not be blank'],       }));  This was actually causing tests to pass that shouldn't have because of the simple nature of Ember.inspect. E.g. comparing strings: "Error: The backend rejected the commit because it was invalid: {errors: [object Object]}"
Message Abstract: Use the correct interface for InvalidError

Message: Run findHasMany inside an ED runloop
Description: In https://github.com/emberjs/data/pull/2576 we added a runloop inside ED, in order to handle relationship deserializing and make sure we coalesce hasMany /belongsTo changes. However in that PR we missed the findHasMany call, causing us to trigger a flush(triggering an arrayWill/DidChange) once for every record being parsed. This commit ensures we first process all the records together, and then call flush only once. Was not sure how test this without a super specific unit test. fixes #2856
Message Abstract: Run findHasMany inside an ED runloop
Description Abstract: In link we added a runloop inside ED, in order to handle relationship deserializing and make sure we coalesce hasMany /belongsTo changes. However in that PR we missed the findHasMany call, causing us to trigger a flush(triggering an arrayWill/DidChange) once for every record being parsed. This commit ensures we first process all the records together, and then call flush only once. Was not sure how test this without a super specific unit test. fixes #2856

Description: Add main entry point for package.json.
Description Abstract: Add main entry point for package.json.

Message: Add main entry point for package.json.
Description: Without this change, Ember CLI 0.2.0 will have the following warning for all ember-data + ember-cli users: % ember s The package `ember-data` is not a properly formatted package, we have used a fallback lookup to resolve it at `/some-path/goes/here/node_modules/ember-data`. This is generally caused by an addon not having a `main` entry point (or `index.js`).
Message Abstract: Add main entry point for package.json.
Description Abstract: Without this change, Ember CLI 0.2.0 will have the following warning for all ember-data + ember-cli users: % ember s The package module is not a properly formatted package, we have used a fallback lookup to resolve it at module. This is generally caused by an addon not having a module entry point (or module).

Description: CLean up implicit relationships on record unload
Description Abstract: CLean up implicit relationships on record unload

Message: CLean up implicit relationships on record unload
Description: Previously if you had records such as: ``` var Group = DS.Model.extend({   people: hasMany('person') }); var Person = DS.Model.extend({   name: attr() }); ``` If you unloaded the person, it would not get removed from it's group. We now properly clean the implicit relationships, so now the person gets removed properly.
Message Abstract: CLean up implicit relationships on record unload
Description Abstract: Previously if you had records such as: module If you unloaded the person, it would not get removed from it's group. We now properly clean the implicit relationships, so now the person gets removed properly.

Description: Adds support for using mixins in polymorphic relationships
Description Abstract: Adds support for using mixins in polymorphic relationships

Message: Adds support for using mixins in polymorphic relationships
Description: Now it's possible to reference mixins in polymorphic relationships. For example: var Comment = DS.Model.extend({      owner: belongsTo('commentable'. { polymorphic: true })   });   var Commentable = Ember.Mixin.create({     comments: hasMany('comment')   });
Message Abstract: Adds support for using mixins in polymorphic relationships
Description Abstract: Now it's possible to reference mixins in polymorphic relationships. For example: var Comment = DS.Model.extend({      owner: belongsTo('commentable'. { polymorphic: true })   });   var Commentable = Ember.Mixin.create({     comments: hasMany('comment')   });

Message: Replace calls to container with registry
Description: Ember.Registry has not yet landed on stable, but floods the console with deprecation warnings for beta and canary. This PR replaces all calls of env.container.register with env.registry.register throughout the test suite. When the Registry is available, it will handle registration. Otherwise, it will defer to the Container.
Message Abstract: Replace calls to container with registry
Description Abstract: Ember.Registry has not yet landed on stable, but floods the console with deprecation warnings for beta and canary. This PR replaces all calls of env.container.register with env.registry.register throughout the test suite. When the Registry is available, it will handle registration. Otherwise, it will defer to the Container.

Message: Sort query params in ajax calls.
Description: When developing APIs, is pretty common to place a high level caching mechanism, like Varnish, to cache requests to public API endpoints, and those tools use the URL string to determine if they have a cached response. As an example, if one user requests /posts?sort=price&category=pets and another requests /posts?category=pets&sort=price, the cached request won't be used in the second call. Varnish by example has some modules to sort query parameters when caching, but it's not the default behavior and requires custom config. Although the URL specification does not say that the order of the query parameters is meaningless, in the bast mayority (read: all) of the APIs I've seen, 2 requests are considered identical regardless of the the order. Because of that, sorting the query params consistenlty is considered a good practice, so this PR introduces a sortQueryParams key in the RESTAdapter class, that defaults to a function to sort query params alphabetically. In case you don't want this behavior, setting that property to a falsey value in the ApplicationAdapter will respect the original order. In case you want a different order, you can pass a function that does the sorting your way. As other customization in ED, this can be customized on a per resource level, in case the order matters in only a few endpoints.
Message Abstract: Sort query params in ajax calls.
Description Abstract: When developing APIs, is pretty common to place a high level caching mechanism, like Varnish, to cache requests to public API endpoints, and those tools use the URL string to determine if they have a cached response. As an example, if one user requests /posts?sort=price&category=pets and another requests /posts?category=pets&sort=price, the cached request won't be used in the second call. Varnish by example has some modules to sort query parameters when caching, but it's not the default behavior and requires custom config. Although the URL specification does not say that the order of the query parameters is meaningless, in the bast mayority (read: all) of the APIs I've seen, 2 requests are considered identical regardless of the the order. Because of that, sorting the query params consistenlty is considered a good practice, so this PR introduces a sortQueryParams key in the RESTAdapter class, that defaults to a function to sort query params alphabetically. In case you don't want this behavior, setting that property to a falsey value in the ApplicationAdapter will respect the original order. In case you want a different order, you can pass a function that does the sorting your way. As other customization in ED, this can be customized on a per resource level, in case the order matters in only a few endpoints.

Description: [DOCS]Update about defining application's store
Description Abstract: [DOCS]Update about defining application's store

Description: Previously, when you've defined store, like outdated documentation suggested: ~~~~ MyApp.Store = DS.Store.extend(); ~~~~ It raised deprecation warning: ~~~~  DEPRECATION: Specifying a custom Store for Ember Data on your global namespace as App.Store has been deprecated. Please use App.ApplicationStore instead.         at ember$data$lib$initializers$store$$initializeStore (http://builds.emberjs.com/canary/ember-data.js:10308:13)         at ember$data$lib$setup$container$$setupContainer (http://builds.emberjs.com/canary/ember-data.js:10621:7)         at http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:3079:11         at visit (http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:2002:7)         at visit (http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:2000:9)         at DAG.topsort (http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:2114:11)         at Namespace.extend.runInitializers (http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:3076:15)         at Namespace.extend._initialize (http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:2961:14)         at Object.Backburner.run (http://builds.emberjs.com/tags/v1.9.1/ember.js:194:27) ~~~~ This is the correct way: ~~~~ MyApp.ApplicationStore = DS.Store.extend(); ~~~~ And this should be in docs.
Description Abstract: Previously, when you've defined store, like outdated documentation suggested: ~~~~ MyApp.Store = DS.Store.extend(); ~~~~ It raised deprecation warning: ~~~~  DEPRECATION: Specifying a custom Store for Ember Data on your global namespace as App.Store has been deprecated. Please use App.ApplicationStore instead.         at ember$data$lib$initializers$store$$initializeStore (link)         at ember$data$lib$setup$container$$setupContainer (link)         at link         at visit (link)         at visit (link)         at DAG.topsort (link)         at Namespace.extend.runInitializers (link)         at Namespace.extend._initialize (link)         at Object.Backburner.run (link) ~~~~ This is the correct way: ~~~~ MyApp.ApplicationStore = DS.Store.extend(); ~~~~ And this should be in docs.

Description: Work around type check issues with MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS.
Description Abstract: Work around type check issues with MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS.

Message: Work around type check issues with MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS.
Description: The container subclasses types retrieved via modelFor, so that if A is a subtype of B, modelFor('model:A') will not be a subtype of modelFor('model:B'). This breaks the type check for polymorphic associations. This commit works around this issue by checking the superclass when doing its type checks, if MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS is enabled.
Message Abstract: Work around type check issues with MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS.
Description Abstract: The container subclasses types retrieved via modelFor, so that if A is a subtype of B, modelFor('model:A') will not be a subtype of modelFor('model:B'). This breaks the type check for polymorphic associations. This commit works around this issue by checking the superclass when doing its type checks, if MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS is enabled.

Message: Schedule relationship normalizaiton and split paths for canonical/client relationship updates
Description: This PR makes several changes to relationship handling: 1. It separates the path through which server side and client side updates happen, which lays the ground work for tracking relationship changes. 2. When pushing records into the store, it splits the push process into three phases using a custom runloop: a) Push primary key data and attribtues b) Turn foreign keys into records c) Update relationships The runloop changes have the effect of making pushing relationships at least 50% faster, more if you have more relationships. It also fixes bugs like #2210
Message Abstract: Schedule relationship normalizaiton and split paths for canonical/client relationship updates
Description Abstract: This PR makes several changes to relationship handling: 1. It separates the path through which server side and client side updates happen, which lays the ground work for tracking relationship changes. 2. When pushing records into the store, it splits the push process into three phases using a custom runloop: a) Push primary key data and attribtues b) Turn foreign keys into records c) Update relationships The runloop changes have the effect of making pushing relationships at least 50% faster, more if you have more relationships. It also fixes bugs like #2210

Description: fix addRecords error iterating over records
Description Abstract: fix addRecords error iterating over records

Message: fix addRecords error iterating over records
Description: Reverts a change in commit c6b451c that used a traditional for loop, assuming that records in addRecords/removeRecords would always be a plain JavaScript array. This assumption was inaccurate. We use the Ember.EnumerableUtils to safely iterate over the objects when forEach/etc arent present. For example, IE8 with Ember.EXTEND_PROTOTYPES = false; fixes Github Issue #2533
Message Abstract: fix addRecords error iterating over records
Description Abstract: Reverts a change in commit c6b451c that used a traditional for loop, assuming that records in addRecords/removeRecords would always be a plain JavaScript array. This assumption was inaccurate. We use the Ember.EnumerableUtils to safely iterate over the objects when forEach/etc arent present. For example, IE8 with Ember.EXTEND_PROTOTYPES = false; fixes Github Issue #2533

Description: I prefer to use DS.attr() without a type when possible, but when I want to use a defaultValue, I must supply a type. This would make it so that you can supply a defaultValue, but still have an attribute without a transform.

Description: warn instead of throw when resolving keys to model
Description Abstract: warn instead of throw when resolving keys to model

Message: warn instead of throw when resolving keys to model
Description: Before this commit, if you had a payload like: javascript {   posts: [] } But didnt have a post model defined, Ember Data would blow up. As discussed in the data team meeting, we decided to warn if the model could not be resolved. In this spirit, Ember Data just doesnt process what it doesnt understand, but can still provide you with a better debugging message to give you hints on what your payload should look like. fixes GH-2337
Message Abstract: warn instead of throw when resolving keys to model
Description Abstract: Before this commit, if you had a payload like: javascript {   posts: [] } But didnt have a post model defined, Ember Data would blow up. As discussed in the data team meeting, we decided to warn if the model could not be resolved. In this spirit, Ember Data just doesnt process what it doesnt understand, but can still provide you with a better debugging message to give you hints on what your payload should look like. fixes GH-2337

Message: Temporary fix for #2344 rollback after delete for recordArrays
Description: This is a temporary fix, it's clear this code needs to be refactored. Moreover I am not sure that removing deleted records from recordArrays before they are deleted is a correct design decision.
Message Abstract: Temporary fix for #2344 rollback after delete for recordArrays
Description Abstract: This is a temporary fix, it's clear this code needs to be refactored. Moreover I am not sure that removing deleted records from recordArrays before they are deleted is a correct design decision.

Message: Do not clear own relationships when deleting records
Description: If a record had a relationship, such as a comment having a post, previously if you did comment.deleteRecord(), comment.get('post') would immediately be set to null. This behavior was wrong for several reasons:   1.It prevented future rollback support for relationships   2.If you had nested URLs, you would not be able to send a DELETE request to /post/1/comments/1     because comment.get('post') would already have been deleted We now only clear the inverse side of the relationships when the record is deleted. The resulting refactor also enables us to add support for a record in a 404 state to be removed from relationships and for removing records from manyArrays that do not have inverses.
Message Abstract: Do not clear own relationships when deleting records
Description Abstract: If a record had a relationship, such as a comment having a post, previously if you did comment.deleteRecord(), comment.get('post') would immediately be set to null. This behavior was wrong for several reasons:   1.It prevented future rollback support for relationships   2.If you had nested URLs, you would not be able to send a DELETE request to /post/1/comments/1     because comment.get('post') would already have been deleted We now only clear the inverse side of the relationships when the record is deleted. The resulting refactor also enables us to add support for a record in a 404 state to be removed from relationships and for removing records from manyArrays that do not have inverses.

Description: Sync ssot
Description Abstract: Sync ssot

Description: This commit refactors relationship handling code. It adds full support for loading relationships described on only one side in the api. It sets up the infrastructure for separating server vs local updates to relationships. In a future PR, we will use that infrastructure to add support for rollback, relationship dirtying and relationship merging. Lots of old, crappy code, removed, -550 lines before new tests. Pushing records into the store is now 15-20% faster. Relationships now properly refetch if the links value is updated. We no longer churn records that are not changed in a hasMany push. fixes #1919 fixes #1814 fixes #2057 fixes #2191 fixes #2177 fixes #2125 fixes #2100 fixes #1790 fixes #1532 fixes #1389
Description Abstract: This commit refactors relationship handling code. It adds full support for loading relationships described on only one side in the api. It sets up the infrastructure for separating server vs local updates to relationships. In a future PR, we will use that infrastructure to add support for rollback, relationship dirtying and relationship merging. Lots of old, crappy code, removed, -550 lines before new tests. Pushing records into the store is now 15-20% faster. Relationships now properly refetch if the links value is updated. We no longer churn records that are not changed in a hasMany push. fixes #1919 fixes #1814 fixes #2057 fixes #2191 fixes #2177 fixes #2125 fixes #2100 fixes #1790 fixes #1532 fixes #1389

Message: [Bugfix] relationship changes shouldnt cause async fetches
Description: As it turns out, we never actuality apply relationship syncing to async relationships, all the code would do was get the relationship which could cause fetches and the bail before the synchronization occurred. This merely moves the guard higher, and changes the guard to be side-affect free. Later work must happen to introduce relationship syncing for async relationships.
Message Abstract: [Bugfix] relationship changes shouldnt cause async fetches
Description Abstract: As it turns out, we never actuality apply relationship syncing to async relationships, all the code would do was get the relationship which could cause fetches and the bail before the synchronization occurred. This merely moves the guard higher, and changes the guard to be side-affect free. Later work must happen to introduce relationship syncing for async relationships.

Description: Coalesce find requests, add support for preloading data
Description Abstract: Coalesce find requests, add support for preloading data

Message: Coalesce find requests, add support for preloading data
Description: This PR brings following improvements/changes:  Find calls from the same runloop will be coalesced into findMany requests if the adapter has a findMany method Adds a groupRecordsForFindMany hook on the adapter that allows you to decide how to coalesce the record requests. This will enable fixing of bugs such as #651, by segmenting on the number of records Allows users to preset attributes and relationships on a model when doing a find call. For relationships you can either pass in a record or an id Gives rudimentary support for nested urls, by passing in the record object to the buildUrl method Removes the owner being passed to findMany becuase it can be looked up on the original record Adds couple special cased SSOT features that were needed for buildUrl/removal of owner property to be viable  This PR lays the groundwork for: 1. Adding support for reloading hasManys 2. Making nice sugar for nestedUrls in the RestAdater
Message Abstract: Coalesce find requests, add support for preloading data
Description Abstract: This PR brings following improvements/changes: Find calls from the same runloop will be coalesced into findMany requests if the adapter has a findMany method Adds a groupRecordsForFindMany hook on the adapter that allows you to decide how to coalesce the record requests. This will enable fixing of bugs such as #651, by segmenting on the number of records Allows users to preset attributes and relationships on a model when doing a find call. For relationships you can either pass in a record or an id Gives rudimentary support for nested urls, by passing in the record object to the buildUrl method Removes the owner being passed to findMany becuase it can be looked up on the original record Adds couple special cased SSOT features that were needed for buildUrl/removal of owner property to be viable This PR lays the groundwork for: 1. Adding support for reloading hasManys 2. Making nice sugar for nestedUrls in the RestAdater

Message: Refactored EmbeddedRecordsMixin to push records instead of sideload
Description: Previously EmbeddedRecordsMixin just moved records around and relied on sideloading for their extraction. Now they are pushed to the store as they are parsed. Benefits include: 1. Less confusing code 2. Out of the box sideloading support 3. Support for using EmbeddedRecordsMixin with JSONSerializer
Message Abstract: Refactored EmbeddedRecordsMixin to push records instead of sideload
Description Abstract: Previously EmbeddedRecordsMixin just moved records around and relied on sideloading for their extraction. Now they are pushed to the store as they are parsed. Benefits include: 1. Less confusing code 2. Out of the box sideloading support 3. Support for using EmbeddedRecordsMixin with JSONSerializer

Description: PERF: O(n) -> O(1) record within recordArray check
Description Abstract: PERF: O(n) -> O(1) record within recordArray check

Message: PERF: O(n) -> O(1) record within recordArray check
Description: If a record changes, we attempt to re-add it to the array, addRecord only adds unique records to the array but does so with an O(n) indexOf. A proper solution would be for addRecord to utilize an index, unfortunately it does not (yet). Luckily we already have just such an index, that records recordArrays map.
Message Abstract: PERF: O(n) -> O(1) record within recordArray check
Description Abstract: If a record changes, we attempt to re-add it to the array, addRecord only adds unique records to the array but does so with an O(n) indexOf. A proper solution would be for addRecord to utilize an index, unfortunately it does not (yet). Luckily we already have just such an index, that records recordArrays map.

Message: Favour declared mapping over keyForAttribute, if defined;
Description: keyForAttribute, if defined, is useful for defining custom changes for all keys on a particular serializer, be it for the application or just a particular resource. The custom attr-based mapping should be maintained, and should precedence, over the keyForAttribute. Broke down the ternary operators for increased readability. Adds integration test for mapping > keyForAttribute precedence

Description Abstract: keyForAttribute, if defined, is useful for defining custom changes for all keys on a particular serializer, be it for the application or just a particular resource. Message: Fixes hasMany records being duplicated after payload returns from server
Description: There is an edge case where a hasMany record gets duplicated (same ID). Basically, if we generate a record locally using UUID or any custom ID format, then push it to production which will return the same ID previously defined, the store's array that holds records to be resolved is going to duplicate both items, even if they have the same ID. This commit fixes that by not allowing duplicated IDs in that array.
Message Abstract: Fixes hasMany records being duplicated after payload returns from server
Description Abstract: There is an edge case where a hasMany record gets duplicated (same ID). Basically, if we generate a record locally using UUID or any custom ID format, then push it to production which will return the same ID previously defined, the store's array that holds records to be resolved is going to duplicate both items, even if they have the same ID. This commit fixes that by not allowing duplicated IDs in that array.

Message: Copy metadata when it is assigned to recordArrays
Description: Currently metadata is saved on Model classes, such that there is only ever 1 instance of the meta object in existence. Often however metadata is a property of a particular array of records and not the record type. A good example is pagination. It should be possible to do store.findQuery() twice and get two arrays where each has it's own meta information. However, because metadata is stored on the Model class, any subsequent request will modify the original pagination metadata. This commit enables each recordArray to have it's own unchanging Meta object.
Message Abstract: Copy metadata when it is assigned to recordArrays
Description Abstract: Currently metadata is saved on Model classes, such that there is only ever 1 instance of the meta object in existence. Often however metadata is a property of a particular array of records and not the record type. A good example is pagination. It should be possible to do store.findQuery() twice and get two arrays where each has it's own meta information. However, because metadata is stored on the Model class, any subsequent request will modify the original pagination metadata. This commit enables each recordArray to have it's own unchanging Meta object.

Message: Do not cache model factories on meta, or on other model CPs
Description: Relationships are hard. Ember-Data has been storing data about a relationship on the meta value for that CP. CPs hang around though, and as a result that data on the meta becomes a cache. For some details about a relationship, this is fine. If User has many Posts, and you use User via a container, it would cache a reference to the Post factory. But if you then destroy that container, the reference to Post still exists in the CP meta. Furthermore, if you create a new container and use User and Post via that new container, the cache factory value for Post will be that of the old container and not the new container. This only is a problem if you expect to have Post be a different factory in each container. In ember-cli, MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS are enabled. This means all factories are extended before being returned by the container. So every time you have a new container, you have a new factory (though it looks and behaves the same). This change gets rid of that cache on meta. Instead it creates a function that accepts the store and meta, and returns the relationship object expected throughout Ember-Data. Two alternatives were considered:  Always check against typeKey instead of instanceof, but this felt like a dodge of the real problem and would leave the issue for others to find, or Create a new first-class relationship object, but this would be a far more invasive change, and would impact much of the codebase that the current relationship object has already leaked through.  Additionally, the types were being cached on model class-level CPs. For this patch, those have simply been marked cacheable(false). A later patch should refactor the CPs out of the way, or at least re-write their consumers to expect a relationship object without the factory itself already fetched.
Message Abstract: Do not cache model factories on meta, or on other model CPs
Description Abstract: Relationships are hard. Ember-Data has been storing data about a relationship on the meta value for that CP. CPs hang around though, and as a result that data on the meta becomes a cache. For some details about a relationship, this is fine. If User has many Posts, and you use User via a container, it would cache a reference to the Post factory. But if you then destroy that container, the reference to Post still exists in the CP meta. Furthermore, if you create a new container and use User and Post via that new container, the cache factory value for Post will be that of the old container and not the new container. This only is a problem if you expect to have Post be a different factory in each container. In ember-cli, MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS are enabled. This means all factories are extended before being returned by the container. So every time you have a new container, you have a new factory (though it looks and behaves the same). This change gets rid of that cache on meta. Instead it creates a function that accepts the store and meta, and returns the relationship object expected throughout Ember-Data. Two alternatives were considered: Always check against typeKey instead of instanceof, but this felt like a dodge of the real problem and would leave the issue for others to find, or Create a new first-class relationship object, but this would be a far more invasive change, and would impact much of the codebase that the current relationship object has already leaked through. Additionally, the types were being cached on model class-level CPs. For this patch, those have simply been marked cacheable(false). A later patch should refactor the CPs out of the way, or at least re-write their consumers to expect a relationship object without the factory itself already fetched.

Description: normalizePayload has been living a lie. It claims to be passed the model type when called, but in often does not receive this argument (null is passed instead). This only serves to confuse the use-case for normalizePayload, and encourage its use when overriding an extraction helper is actually the right choice. This tradeoff, dropping the argument of type in all cases, means normalizePayload can still be run over data added with pushPayload. pushPayload knows nothing of which model is being pushed, and thus cannot provide the type reliably.
Description Abstract: normalizePayload has been living a lie. It claims to be passed the model type when called, but in often does not receive this argument (null is passed instead). This only serves to confuse the use-case for normalizePayload, and encourage its use when overriding an extraction helper is actually the right choice. This tradeoff, dropping the argument of type in all cases, means normalizePayload can still be run over data added with pushPayload. pushPayload knows nothing of which model is being pushed, and thus cannot provide the type reliably.

Message: [BUGFIX] Normalize typeKeys to always be camelCase
Description: typeKeys must have a strong formatting convention, since they are used for comparison in several spots of the code. Prior to this commit:  The container's normalized version of the factory name was set to     the typeKey. This leaked the container concerns about name     formatting up to Ember-Data, and to the user's interaction with     API calls like find('some-module') The typeKey property of a model class was allowed to pass into the     code without normalization.  In general, for a developer to know which to pick of find('some-car'), find('someCar') or find('some_cars') they had to understand which resolver their container was using. This demonstrates a bad coupling, and makes documenting Ember-Data exceedingly hard (we should not need to mention a caveat about picking a resolver). This commit normalizes typeKeys to always be camelCase, both those returned by typeForRoot (for which the documentation has been improved) and for those set on factories by modelFor. From here on, find('someCar') should be considered the standard format for multi-word model names.
Message Abstract: [BUGFIX] Normalize typeKeys to always be camelCase
Description Abstract: typeKeys must have a strong formatting convention, since they are used for comparison in several spots of the code. Prior to this commit: The container's normalized version of the factory name was set to     the typeKey. This leaked the container concerns about name     formatting up to Ember-Data, and to the user's interaction with     API calls like find('some-module') The typeKey property of a model class was allowed to pass into the     code without normalization. In general, for a developer to know which to pick of find('some-car'), find('someCar') or find('some_cars') they had to understand which resolver their container was using. This demonstrates a bad coupling, and makes documenting Ember-Data exceedingly hard (we should not need to mention a caveat about picking a resolver). This commit normalizes typeKeys to always be camelCase, both those returned by typeForRoot (for which the documentation has been improved) and for those set on factories by modelFor. From here on, find('someCar') should be considered the standard format for multi-word model names.

Message: Refactor Ember initializer to use DS._setupContainer
Description: The container setup used by Ember-Data has been coupled to the Ember.js application initialization code. This splits the container setup into a separate set of files, allowing container setup to be used in testing environments that have not booted an application. Testing environments should use the new DS._setupContainer API: var container = new Ember.Container(); DS._setupContainer(container); var store = container.lookup('store:main');  DS._setupContainer will configure the container for ember-data proper and for the activemode-adapter package. This API uses an _ as a warning to consumers: It may change.
Message Abstract: Refactor Ember initializer to use DS._setupContainer
Description Abstract: The container setup used by Ember-Data has been coupled to the Ember.js application initialization code. This splits the container setup into a separate set of files, allowing container setup to be used in testing environments that have not booted an application. Testing environments should use the new DS._setupContainer API: var container = new Ember.Container(); DS._setupContainer(container); var store = container.lookup('store:main'); DS._setupContainer will configure the container for ember-data proper and for the activemode-adapter package. This API uses an _ as a warning to consumers: It may change.

Message: Deprecate App.Store in favor of App.ApplicationStore.
Description: This makes the application level store lookup much closer to the reset of our conventions (ala App.ApplicationAdapter and App.ApplicationSerializer). This change also allows specifying a custom store when using non-global resolver (i.e. EAK/ember-cli). Previously, we were only looking for a property Store hung off of the application instance. Now you can have a module named (in the case of stock EAK setup): app/stores/application or app/application/store.js (pods structure). A deprecation warning was added, and the prior technique still works so this is not a breaking change (although I believe that we should remove before the prior lookup prior to 1.0).
Message Abstract: Deprecate App.Store in favor of App.ApplicationStore.
Description Abstract: This makes the application level store lookup much closer to the reset of our conventions (ala App.ApplicationAdapter and App.ApplicationSerializer). This change also allows specifying a custom store when using non-global resolver (i.e. EAK/ember-cli). Previously, we were only looking for a property Store hung off of the application instance. Now you can have a module named (in the case of stock EAK setup): app/stores/application or app/application/store.js (pods structure). A deprecation warning was added, and the prior technique still works so this is not a breaking change (although I believe that we should remove before the prior lookup prior to 1.0).

Message: hasMany relationship property are essentially readOnly, lets mark them as such.
Description: This also fixes a potential issue with minified code changing the arity of these CPs. This happens because "value"'s only purpose is to increase the arity to 2, such that setting to this CP has no effect. Unfortunately, when minified it does have an effect. Also, allowing this property to be set to, even though it has no outcome, is just straight up misleading.

Description Abstract: This also fixes a potential issue with minified code changing the arity of these CPs. This happens because "value"'s only purpose is to increase the arity to 2, such that setting to this CP has no effect. Unfortunately, when minified it does have an effect. Also, allowing this property to be set to, even though it has no outcome, is just straight up misleading.

Message Abstract: Remove restriction for jQuery version in bower.json
Description Abstract: This was needed since Ember v1.3.1 only works with jQuery <2.1, but the bower config for this version didn't specify this restriction. Since this has been fixed by Seor @rjackson (link) the specific jQuery version is removed again from bower.json.

Message: Revert "DateTransform serializes as a number instead of string. The deserializer was already considering this case. Adds millisecond precision to DateTransform"
Description: This reverts commit 47e43938d43cd012c2e89a51c6ea49f74c1c2840. This change causes errors when server-side handling does not support numeric values for dates. Example (Rails backend): PG::DatatypeMismatch: ERROR:  column "received_at" is of type timestamp without time zone but expression is of type bigint
Message Abstract: Revert "DateTransform serializes as a number instead of string. The deserializer was already considering this case. Adds millisecond precision to DateTransform"
Description Abstract: This reverts commit 47e43938d43cd012c2e89a51c6ea49f74c1c2840. This change causes errors when server-side handling does not support numeric values for dates. Example (Rails backend): PG::DatatypeMismatch: ERROR:  column "received_at" is of type timestamp without time zone but expression is of type bigint

Description: The act of finding a model in the store doest not implicitly save the record, thus the record.isNew property would still be true.  The record must be saved/committed to the server and if this promise is fulfilled, then it is no longer considered new. If my assumption is incorrect, and store.find(...) is correct I would still prefer for a something else in code example since there is no clear indication of why finding a model with an id of 1 would imply to find the previously created record.
Description Abstract: The act of finding a model in the store doest not implicitly save the record, thus the record.isNew property would still be true.  The record must be saved/committed to the server and if this promise is fulfilled, then it is no longer considered new. If my assumption is incorrect, and store.find(...) is correct I would still prefer for a something else in code example since there is no clear indication of why finding a model with an id of 1 would imply to find the previously created record.

Description: Having adapters and serializers with underscores in their names is causing issues with Ember Appkit's Resolver. The resolver will normalize the fullpath of the es6 module and calls Ember.String.dashserize on the fullpath. This converts the underscores to dashes, for example: -ams instead of _ams so the lookup becomes app/serializers/-ams and this of course cannot be found. This PR removes what can be argued as an unnecessary attempt to protect the adapter and serializer names from being overwritten, instead the convention to be pushed should be to have the names match the adpter/serializer class name. In addition, the ActiveModelAdapter's name was strangely called _ams and this does't match the class name at all. There is no 's' in the class name at all. Instead this PR has opted to rename both the adapter and the serializer active-model.
Description Abstract: Having adapters and serializers with underscores in their names is causing issues with Ember Appkit's Resolver. The resolver will normalize the fullpath of the es6 module and calls Ember.String.dashserize on the fullpath. This converts the underscores to dashes, for example: -ams instead of _ams so the lookup becomes app/serializers/-ams and this of course cannot be found. This PR removes what can be argued as an unnecessary attempt to protect the adapter and serializer names from being overwritten, instead the convention to be pushed should be to have the names match the adpter/serializer class name. In addition, the ActiveModelAdapter's name was strangely called _ams and this does't match the class name at all. There is no 's' in the class name at all. Instead this PR has opted to rename both the adapter and the serializer active-model.

Message: Fix Travis failures and publishing of builds.
Description: Updates to the latest ember-dev which ensures that the git config user.name and git config user.email values are present before calling git cherry-pick. This is due to a recent change in git 1.8.5 which requires the user information be present prior to a cherry-pick. Travis accidentally reverted to using an older git version that does not support the --points-at flag that we are using in ember-dev. This forces the system to upgrade to the latest version. Travis ticket for reference: https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/1710.
Message Abstract: Fix Travis failures and publishing of builds.
Description Abstract: Updates to the latest ember-dev which ensures that the git config user.name and git config user.email values are present before calling git cherry-pick. This is due to a recent change in git 1.8.5 which requires the user information be present prior to a cherry-pick. Travis accidentally reverted to using an older git version that does not support the --points-at flag that we are using in ember-dev. This forces the system to upgrade to the latest version. Travis ticket for reference: link.

Description: Some minifier keep header comment over its format.  YUI Compressor It keeps the header comments beggining with /*!  http://yui.github.io/yuicompressor/css.html#special-comments   Closure compiler It keeps the header comments containing @license or @preserve  https://developers.google.com/closure/compiler/docs/js-for-compiler#tag-license  I think header comment is very important because it includes its own license.
Message Abstract: Update header comment format to keep it on minify
Description Abstract: Some minifier keep header comment over its format. YUI Compressor It keeps the header comments beggining with /*! link Closure compiler It keeps the header comments containing @license or @preserve link I think header comment is very important because it includes its own license.

Description: Throw instead of assert in modelFor when type can't be resolved.
Description Abstract: Throw instead of assert in modelFor when type can't be resolved.

Message: Throw instead of assert in modelFor when type can't be resolved.
Description: Background: Asserts are stripped out of production builds. In production, it is possible that a root key in an API response changes in a way that your serializer's typeForRoot implementation does not convert properly. Since the assert in modelFor is stripped in production builds, the javascript error raised in a production environment would be: "Cannot set property 'typeKey' on undefined" This commit changes the assert to a check and throw so the error raised would be something like: "No model was found for 'home_planet'" The provides a much more helpful error for real-world production errors at a relatively small price (one extra line of code and a simple value check).
Message Abstract: Throw instead of assert in modelFor when type can't be resolved.
Description Abstract: Background: Asserts are stripped out of production builds. In production, it is possible that a root key in an API response changes in a way that your serializer's typeForRoot implementation does not convert properly. Since the assert in modelFor is stripped in production builds, the javascript error raised in a production environment would be: "Cannot set property 'typeKey' on undefined" This commit changes the assert to a check and throw so the error raised would be something like: "No model was found for 'home_planet'" The provides a much more helpful error for real-world production errors at a relatively small price (one extra line of code and a simple value check).

Message: Don't bother with Ember.run.once, as we can detect an impending flush
Description: by inspecting the size of the local queue of _deferredTriggers This should mitigate some costly run-loop pressure. Inspired to help with: https://github.com/ebryn/backburner.js/issues/51
Message Abstract: Don't bother with Ember.run.once, as we can detect an impending flush
Description Abstract: by inspecting the size of the local queue of _deferredTriggers This should mitigate some costly run-loop pressure. Inspired to help with: link

Message: Ember.run.once of an anonymous function is just wasteful, as each
Description: invocation creates a new function. All this would do is add some extra work to backburner.
Message Abstract: Ember.run.once of an anonymous function is just wasteful, as each
Description Abstract: invocation creates a new function. All this would do is add some extra work to backburner.

Description: Removing deleted records from RecordArrays is now async.
Description Abstract: Removing deleted records from RecordArrays is now async.

Message: Removing deleted records from RecordArrays is now async.
Description: Previously filtered record arrays were updated asynchronously when records were added, but record arrays were updated synchronously when records were deleted.  This led to surprising behavior such as: ```js myRecordArray.get('length') // => 2 myRecordArray.invoke('deleteRecord'); // we didn't delete everything, because we mutated the record array during iteration myRecordArray.get('length') // => 1 ``` Now all record array updating goes through the same code path. -- David J. Hamilton & Stefan Penner
Message Abstract: Removing deleted records from RecordArrays is now async.
Description Abstract: Previously filtered record arrays were updated asynchronously when records were added, but record arrays were updated synchronously when records were deleted.  This led to surprising behavior such as: module Now all record array updating goes through the same code path. -- David J. Hamilton & Stefan Penner

Message: Allow recordIsLoaded to be called with a string for the type.
Description: recordIsLoaded did not support execution with a string as the type argument, only a DS.Model class reference. This commit makes either form possible. Consistent with find, the type argument is passed through modelFor to resolve a class reference.
Message Abstract: Allow recordIsLoaded to be called with a string for the type.
Description Abstract: recordIsLoaded did not support execution with a string as the type argument, only a DS.Model class reference. This commit makes either form possible. Consistent with find, the type argument is passed through modelFor to resolve a class reference.

Description: This will publish a ember-tests.html static test site along with the builds. This makes it extremely simple to test the latest canary/beta/release builds on various devices. It is also critical to the cross-browser testing that we have been working on.

Description: Update ember-dev to (b0b12c4).
Description Abstract: Update ember-dev to (b0b12c4).

Description: Updates ember-dev to (b0b12c4) which includes the following changes:  Will not attempt to unshallow a full git repo Makes default test suite (packages only) run with features enabled and   disabled. Fixes bug where the wrong Project name is used in the auto-generated   CHANGELOG. Allows overriding the build type. (Simply set ENV['BUILD_TYPE']='canary') Add ember:generate_static_test_site task to create a static HTML   file for running the test suite. Add custom test results gathering for use in cross-browser testing. Make sure that the test file being used in the Assetfile is prefixed   with the proper dasherized project name (prior to this Ember Data   tests were still named ember-tests.js and now they will be   ember-data-tests.js). Fixes issue where local rake test runs would attempt to perform git   operations (checkout and cherry-pick). Now git operations will   only be attempted if ENV['CI']=true.  For further reference: https://github.com/emberjs/ember-dev/compare/0c0743979a...b0b12c4758e26
Description Abstract: Updates ember-dev to (b0b12c4) which includes the following changes: Will not attempt to unshallow a full git repo Makes default test suite (packages only) run with features enabled and   disabled. Fixes bug where the wrong Project name is used in the auto-generated   CHANGELOG. Allows overriding the build type. (Simply set ENV['BUILD_TYPE']='canary') Add ember:generate_static_test_site task to create a static HTML   file for running the test suite. Add custom test results gathering for use in cross-browser testing. Make sure that the test file being used in the Assetfile is prefixed   with the proper dasherized project name (prior to this Ember Data   tests were still named ember-tests.js and now they will be   ember-data-tests.js). Fixes issue where local rake test runs would attempt to perform git   operations (checkout and cherry-pick). Now git operations will   only be attempted if ENV['CI']=true. For further reference: link

Description: Correctly define window/global DS namespace in IE7/8.
Description Abstract: Correctly define window/global DS namespace in IE7/8.

Message: Correctly define window/global DS namespace in IE7/8.
Description: In IE7/8, defining DS globally without directly defining it on window.DS causes it to not appear in the for..in loop that processes namespaces inside of findNamespaces() https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/blob/master/packages/ember-runtime/lib/system/namespace.js#L117 This causes Ember.Namespace.NAMESPACES_BY_ID to contain an undefined key instead of DS, which leads to issues when resolving across different namespaces (such as the DS namespace when using DjangoRESTAdapter), or when generating toString() outputs of the DS namespace or child objects. This change allows one existing, failing test to pass in IE8: https://github.com/emberjs/data/blob/c04b8e47c7de8b158d16bd4850744fec796ca05f/packages/ember-data/tests/unit/model_test.js#L57 which fails because the DS part of the expected toString() output is missing.
Message Abstract: Correctly define window/global DS namespace in IE7/8.
Description Abstract: In IE7/8, defining DS globally without directly defining it on window.DS causes it to not appear in the for..in loop that processes namespaces inside of findNamespaces() link This causes Ember.Namespace.NAMESPACES_BY_ID to contain an undefined key instead of DS, which leads to issues when resolving across different namespaces (such as the DS namespace when using DjangoRESTAdapter), or when generating toString() outputs of the DS namespace or child objects. This change allows one existing, failing test to pass in IE8: link which fails because the DS part of the expected toString() output is missing.

Description: Update ember-dev.
Description Abstract: Update ember-dev.

Description: Major new features:  Automated multi-branch testing for commits with specially formatted   commit messages (BUGFIX, SECURITY, etc). Documentation generator via rake docs task. Automatic publishing of generated docs for each build. Will wait for the Rack server to be ready for connections before   initiating tests (hopefully mitigates the phantomjs timeout issue) Will test each package both with and without feature flags. Will abort tests if defeatureify is not present and a   features.json file exists. Updates to QUnit 1.12.0. Updates to use Puma for automated tests. Many test improvements.  The updated QUnit runner fixes the issue with ember-data causing the moduleDone output (totals for test count, time, errors, failures) to be printed once for each test (instead of only once per module).
Description Abstract: Major new features: Automated multi-branch testing for commits with specially formatted   commit messages (BUGFIX, SECURITY, etc). Documentation generator via rake docs task. Automatic publishing of generated docs for each build. Will wait for the Rack server to be ready for connections before   initiating tests (hopefully mitigates the phantomjs timeout issue) Will test each package both with and without feature flags. Will abort tests if defeatureify is not present and a   features.json file exists. Updates to QUnit 1.12.0. Updates to use Puma for automated tests. Many test improvements. The updated QUnit runner fixes the issue with ember-data causing the moduleDone output (totals for test count, time, errors, failures) to be printed once for each test (instead of only once per module).

Description: Handle absolute / relative paths and full URLs in links
Description Abstract: Handle absolute / relative paths and full URLs in links

Message: handle absolute / relative paths and full URLs in links
Description: fixes #1365 absolute paths start with a leading / and will use only the provided host provided to the adapter cf. { posts: [{ id: 1, links: { comments: "/posts/1/comments" }}] } relative paths construct an URL from the record the relationship is embedded in: cf. { posts: [{ id: 1, links: { comments: "comments" }}] } full URLs links will pass through the link transparently: cf. { posts: [{ id: 1, links: { comments: "http://example.com/posts/1/comments" }}] } note that all of the above examples are equivalent to each other.
Message Abstract: handle absolute / relative paths and full URLs in links
Description Abstract: fixes #1365 absolute paths start with a leading / and will use only the provided host provided to the adapter cf. { posts: [{ id: 1, links: { comments: "/posts/1/comments" }}] } relative paths construct an URL from the record the relationship is embedded in: cf. { posts: [{ id: 1, links: { comments: "comments" }}] } full URLs links will pass through the link transparently: cf. { posts: [{ id: 1, links: { comments: "link" }}] } note that all of the above examples are equivalent to each other.

Description: This is a compatible way for embedded objects using DS.ActiveModelSerializer. In 0.13: javascript DS.RESTAdapter.map('App.Post', {   comments: { embedded: 'always' } }); Using this patch: javascript App.PostSerializer = DS.ActiveModelSerializer.extend({   attrs: {     comments: { embedded: 'always' }   } });
Description Abstract: This is a compatible way for embedded objects using DS.ActiveModelSerializer. In 0.13: javascript DS.RESTAdapter.map('App.Post', {   comments: { embedded: 'always' } }); Using this patch: javascript App.PostSerializer = DS.ActiveModelSerializer.extend({   attrs: {     comments: { embedded: 'always' }   } });

Message: Add documentation for using underscored API endpoings and underscored root objects in JSON responses.
Description: Starting in Beta 1 the RESTAdapter tries to send API requests to '/blog-posts' instead of '/blog_posts' as it had done previously.  It also expects the root object of a JSON response to be camelized instead of underscored.  This PR add info to the TRANSITION document about how to go back to the previous functionality.
Message Abstract: Add documentation for using underscored API endpoings and underscored root objects in JSON responses.
Description Abstract: Starting in Beta 1 the RESTAdapter tries to send API requests to '/blog-posts' instead of '/blog_posts' as it had done previously.  It also expects the root object of a JSON response to be camelized instead of underscored.  This PR add info to the TRANSITION document about how to go back to the previous functionality.

Message: Add store.update to update just some attrs
Description: This also moves the logic for transforms into normalize rather than push, which fixes #1214. It means that you should not rely on push to apply transforms, and must do all normalization before pushing. A nice solution for streamed data is coming.
Message Abstract: Add store.update to update just some attrs
Description Abstract: This also moves the logic for transforms into normalize rather than push, which fixes #1214. It means that you should not rely on push to apply transforms, and must do all normalization before pushing. A nice solution for streamed data is coming.

Description: store.push is a replacement for store.load. It takes a normalized JSON structure and optionally uses a serializer to do additional work if one is available under the type's name. store.recordFor returns an unpopulated record for the given type and id. Future calls to store.push will move it into the loaded state.
Description Abstract: store.push is a replacement for store.load. It takes a normalized JSON structure and optionally uses a serializer to do additional work if one is available under the type's name. store.recordFor returns an unpopulated record for the given type and id. Future calls to store.push will move it into the loaded state.

Message: This PR represents a lot of refactor work on the rest_adapter_test unit tests.
Description: All of the tests which are passing have been modified to match their original passing conditions. There is one failing test included (which I believe is legitimate), that uncovers an issue with sideloading data. Summary of changes: - added flagEquals / stateEquals assertion helpers - added comments for test helpers - removed teardown for tests (all tests remained green after doing so) - cleaned up scoping for tests -- globals only used for configuration, locals used for test data - relocated helper functions to top of test - removed unnecessary var definitions - created a consistent test format: - test setup code is grouped together - test assertion code is grouped together - whitespace between setup and assertion code - comments above each individual assertion and setup block - each test should have a state and flag assertion after a model change state The new flagEquals() assertions and stateEquals() assertions should probably be audited to ensure that the state of the records should actually be what the assertion says they are. While re-writing these tests, I personally disagree with some of the flags set for the given record states.
Message Abstract: This PR represents a lot of refactor work on the rest_adapter_test unit tests.
Description Abstract: All of the tests which are passing have been modified to match their original passing conditions. There is one failing test included (which I believe is legitimate), that uncovers an issue with sideloading data. Summary of changes: - added flagEquals / stateEquals assertion helpers - added comments for test helpers - removed teardown for tests (all tests remained green after doing so) - cleaned up scoping for tests -- globals only used for configuration, locals used for test data - relocated helper functions to top of test - removed unnecessary var definitions - created a consistent test format: - test setup code is grouped together - test assertion code is grouped together - whitespace between setup and assertion code - comments above each individual assertion and setup block - each test should have a state and flag assertion after a model change state The new flagEquals() assertions and stateEquals() assertions should probably be audited to ensure that the state of the records should actually be what the assertion says they are. While re-writing these tests, I personally disagree with some of the flags set for the given record states.

Message: Transition from client IDs to record references
Description: In Ember Data, there needs to be a mechanism for the system to refer to a record that has not yet been loaded. These references need to be as cheap as possible so that loading and processing data does not require materializing many full-blown DS.Models all at once. Previously, the mechanism for referencing unloaded/unmaterialized records was the client ID, a monotonically increasing number. Metadata about the unmaterialized record was saved in several different data structures in the store, indexed by client ID. Unfortunately, as the needs of Ember Data have grown, the number of data structures in the store have increased beyond their initial scope, leading to confusing, opaque code. This commit replaces almost all of the uses of client ID with the notion of a record reference. A reference is a simple JavaScript object that contains all of the metadata for a single record. For example, when you load data into the store via load, it will be saved inside the record reference. When you find the record, via e.g. App.Post.find(1), the materialized record will also be saved inside the record reference. This commit also comes with several convenience methods for dealing with record references on the store.
Message Abstract: Transition from client IDs to record references
Description Abstract: In Ember Data, there needs to be a mechanism for the system to refer to a record that has not yet been loaded. These references need to be as cheap as possible so that loading and processing data does not require materializing many full-blown DS.Models all at once. Previously, the mechanism for referencing unloaded/unmaterialized records was the client ID, a monotonically increasing number. Metadata about the unmaterialized record was saved in several different data structures in the store, indexed by client ID. Unfortunately, as the needs of Ember Data have grown, the number of data structures in the store have increased beyond their initial scope, leading to confusing, opaque code. This commit replaces almost all of the uses of client ID with the notion of a record reference. A reference is a simple JavaScript object that contains all of the metadata for a single record. For example, when you load data into the store via load, it will be saved inside the record reference. When you find the record, via e.g. App.Post.find(1), the materialized record will also be saved inside the record reference. This commit also comes with several convenience methods for dealing with record references on the store.

Message: Only enforce invariants for materialized records
Description: If a record is deleted, its has-many relationships are cleared. Previously, the inverse on all of the child records (their "foreign keys") were nulled out. Unfortunately, this was also happening when the has-many array had not been materializingmeaning that deleting a record could actually cause all of the records in its has-many relationships to be retrieved from the adapter! This commit only implements the above-described behavior in instances where the has-many relationship has been materialized. In cases where it has not been materialized, only those records which have already been coincidentally materialized on the client have their inverse cleared, to preserve the correct state on the client. For unmaterialized records, we assume the adapter (or more likely, the server, in the case of REST) will be responsible for maintaining the invariant. Also, this fixes the previous failing unit tests. Sorry about that.
Message Abstract: Only enforce invariants for materialized records
Description Abstract: If a record is deleted, its has-many relationships are cleared. Previously, the inverse on all of the child records (their "foreign keys") were nulled out. Unfortunately, this was also happening when the has-many array had not been materializingmeaning that deleting a record could actually cause all of the records in its has-many relationships to be retrieved from the adapter! This commit only implements the above-described behavior in instances where the has-many relationship has been materialized. In cases where it has not been materialized, only those records which have already been coincidentally materialized on the client have their inverse cleared, to preserve the correct state on the client. For unmaterialized records, we assume the adapter (or more likely, the server, in the case of REST) will be responsible for maintaining the invariant. Also, this fixes the previous failing unit tests. Sorry about that.

Description: App.User = DS.Model.extend({  messages: DS.hasMany(App.Message, {polymorphic: true}) }); App.Message = DS.Model.extend({   created_at: DS.attr('date'),   user: DS.belongsTo(App.User) }); App.Post = App.Message.extend({   title: DS.attr('string') }); App.Comment = App.Message.extend({   body: DS.attr('string'),   message: DS.belongsTo(App.Message, {polymorphic: true}) }); You need to configure the serializer to map to the correct type: DS.RESTAdapter.configure('App.Post' {   alias: 'post' }); DS.RESTAdapter.configure('App.Comment' {   alias: 'comment' }); Initializing an alias will automatically allow you to sideload this type. The support for sideloadAs is only for backward compatibility. Two hooks exist for the serialization and materialization of an embedded polymorphic association: * addType that adds the record's type to the serialized data * extractEmbeddedType that retrieves the record's type from the payload. Both hooks rely in the JSONSerializer on keyForEmbeddedType, which returns the string used to represent the record's type in the payload. The default value is 'type'
Description Abstract: App.User = DS.Model.extend({  messages: DS.hasMany(App.Message, {polymorphic: true}) }); App.Message = DS.Model.extend({   created_at: DS.attr('date'),   user: DS.belongsTo(App.User) }); App.Post = App.Message.extend({   title: DS.attr('string') }); App.Comment = App.Message.extend({   body: DS.attr('string'),   message: DS.belongsTo(App.Message, {polymorphic: true}) }); You need to configure the serializer to map to the correct type: DS.RESTAdapter.configure('App.Post' {   alias: 'post' }); DS.RESTAdapter.configure('App.Comment' {   alias: 'comment' }); Initializing an alias will automatically allow you to sideload this type. The support for sideloadAs is only for backward compatibility. Two hooks exist for the serialization and materialization of an embedded polymorphic association: * addType that adds the record's type to the serialized data * extractEmbeddedType that retrieves the record's type from the payload. Both hooks rely in the JSONSerializer on keyForEmbeddedType, which returns the string used to represent the record's type in the payload. The default value is 'type'

Message: automatically publish passing master branch builds to s3
Description: This commit will publish passing builds of the master branch to s3 for convenient downloading. Files created if the build is successful: ember-data-latest.js ember-data-latest.min.js ember-data-.js ember-data-.min.js Any -latest.js files will be overwritten to the build that passes and runs rake publish_build. To add credentials to your travis instance: gem install travis travis encrypt S3_ACCESS_KEY_ID=yourkey --add travis encrypt S3_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=yourkey --add You'll also need to update the S3_BUCKET_NAME=yourbucketname in .travis.yml
Message Abstract: automatically publish passing master branch builds to s3
Description Abstract: This commit will publish passing builds of the master branch to s3 for convenient downloading. Files created if the build is successful: ember-data-latest.js ember-data-latest.min.js ember-data-.js ember-data-.min.js Any -latest.js files will be overwritten to the build that passes and runs rake publish_build. To add credentials to your travis instance: gem install travis travis encrypt S3_ACCESS_KEY_ID=yourkey --add travis encrypt S3_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=yourkey --add You'll also need to update the S3_BUCKET_NAME=yourbucketname in .travis.yml

Message: Created embedded records should dirty parent
Description: Previously, embedded records (those without IDs) that were created via ManyArray's createRecord method were not properly being saved, nor dirtying the parent's tree. This commit ensures that an embedded record's parent is saved on its reference when it is added to the many array for the first time.
Message Abstract: Created embedded records should dirty parent
Description Abstract: Previously, embedded records (those without IDs) that were created via ManyArray's createRecord method were not properly being saved, nor dirtying the parent's tree. This commit ensures that an embedded record's parent is saved on its reference when it is added to the many array for the first time.

Message: Address issue with embedded hasMany creation
Description: Fixes #633. This ensures that when creating a new record in an embedded hasMany relationship, either via post.get('comments').createRecord or via Comment.createRecord({ post: post }), both the child and parent will become dirty. This retains the "dirty tree" semantics, which will walk up and down the tree of embedded relationships and mark things dirty.
Message Abstract: Address issue with embedded hasMany creation
Description Abstract: Fixes #633. This ensures that when creating a new record in an embedded hasMany relationship, either via post.get('comments').createRecord or via Comment.createRecord({ post: post }), both the child and parent will become dirty. This retains the "dirty tree" semantics, which will walk up and down the tree of embedded relationships and mark things dirty.

Message: The owner record is now an argument passed to findMany on the adapter
Description: While writing an adapter for my django backend I was unable to build a valid url for my hasMany relationships because the owner was not easily accessible. Going forward the owner will now be an argument available for custom adapters like the one I ended up writing. example of how my REST api would lookup hasMany relationships: If I have a person with many occupations I would look them up like so /people/1/occupations/ Notice the id 1 above is actually the owner of the occupations (not a occupation id from the ids array that is passed into findMany) Instead of passing each id like the built in RESTAdapter the url above just expects the owner will know how to find each occupation
Message Abstract: The owner record is now an argument passed to findMany on the adapter
Description Abstract: While writing an adapter for my django backend I was unable to build a valid url for my hasMany relationships because the owner was not easily accessible. Going forward the owner will now be an argument available for custom adapters like the one I ended up writing. example of how my REST api would lookup hasMany relationships: If I have a person with many occupations I would look them up like so /people/1/occupations/ Notice the id 1 above is actually the owner of the occupations (not a occupation id from the ids array that is passed into findMany) Instead of passing each id like the built in RESTAdapter the url above just expects the owner will know how to find each occupation

Description: By adding a pingbacks relationship and not modifying it in any test, we should end up with an empty array in all serialized Posts, i.e. {     "post": {         "comments": [             {                 "title": "Wouldn't a more lightweight...",                 "user": null             },             {                 "title": "This does not seem to reflect...",                 "user": null             }         ],         "pingbacks": [],         "title": "A New MVC Framework in Under 100 Lines of Code"     } }  However, what we get is {     "post": {         "comments": [             {                 "title": "Wouldn't a more lightweight...",                 "user": null             },             {                 "title": "This does not seem to reflect...",                 "user": null             }         ],         "pingbacks": [             {                 "title": "Wouldn't a more lightweight...",                 "user": null             },             {                 "title": "This does not seem to reflect...",                 "user": null             }         ],         "title": "A New MVC Framework in Under 100 Lines of Code"     } }
Description Abstract: By adding a pingbacks relationship and not modifying it in any test, we should end up with an empty array in all serialized Posts, i.e. {     "post": {         "comments": [             {                 "title": "Wouldn't a more lightweight...",                 "user": null             },             {                 "title": "This does not seem to reflect...",                 "user": null             }         ],         "pingbacks": [],         "title": "A New MVC Framework in Under 100 Lines of Code"     } } However, what we get is {     "post": {         "comments": [             {                 "title": "Wouldn't a more lightweight...",                 "user": null             },             {                 "title": "This does not seem to reflect...",                 "user": null             }         ],         "pingbacks": [             {                 "title": "Wouldn't a more lightweight...",                 "user": null             },             {                 "title": "This does not seem to reflect...",                 "user": null             }         ],         "title": "A New MVC Framework in Under 100 Lines of Code"     } }

Description: This commit adds the ability for the adapter to specify which records should be marked dirty when changes occur, such as when an attribute or relationship changes.
