If you are using the REST adapter, it should not introduce any breaking changes. For more information about the rationale behind this change, please see BREAKING_CHANGES.md, revision 9.

Description: Pass type into findQuery. This allows you to do custom query logic based on what kind of fixtures are requested. Now you can switch your query logic if Todo or Message is queried. This logic would normally be done on the server, but you can implement it here for development purposes.
Description Abstract: Pass type into findQuery. This allows you to do custom query logic based on what kind of fixtures are requested. Now you can switch your query logic if Todo or Message is queried. This logic would normally be done on the server, but you can implement it here for development purposes.

Description: Fix relationship change when restoring old value
Description Abstract: Fix relationship change when restoring old value

Message: Fix relationship change when restoring old value
Description: This addresses two issues:  Restoring the child to the original value  This is necessary when the restoration is triggered by a change on   the parent.  Removing the dirty factor from lastParent (the penultimate parent)  Aside from actually removing the dirty factor in the destroy(), this   also requires suspending lastParent's association observers when   removing the child from it. If that didn't happen, lastParent's arrayContentWillChange() would   set newParent to null and trigger another sync of the relationship   change, which would then cause lastParent to get set to null before   the change's destroy() can be called.
Message Abstract: Fix relationship change when restoring old value
Description Abstract: This addresses two issues: Restoring the child to the original value This is necessary when the restoration is triggered by a change on   the parent. Removing the dirty factor from lastParent (the penultimate parent) Aside from actually removing the dirty factor in the destroy(), this   also requires suspending lastParent's association observers when   removing the child from it. If that didn't happen, lastParent's arrayContentWillChange() would   set newParent to null and trigger another sync of the relationship   change, which would then cause lastParent to get set to null before   the change's destroy() can be called.

Description: The basic use-case for this is when a hasMany comes back from the server as a URL. Previously, extractHasMany in the serializer always returns an Array, which is an Array of adapter IDs. This commit allows extractHasMany to return an opaque hash. If such a hash is returned, the store will call the adapter's findAssociation method instead of findMany, passing through the hash. The findAssociation hook is responsible for calling store.materializeHasMany(model, key, ids), which fills in the hasMany association and marks it as loaded.
Description Abstract: The basic use-case for this is when a hasMany comes back from the server as a URL. Previously, extractHasMany in the serializer always returns an Array, which is an Array of adapter IDs. This commit allows extractHasMany to return an opaque hash. If such a hash is returned, the store will call the adapter's findAssociation method instead of findMany, passing through the hash. The findAssociation hook is responsible for calling store.materializeHasMany(model, key, ids), which fills in the hasMany association and marks it as loaded.

Description: It turned out to be possible for a relationship change to exist even if no child record existed. This happened if a parent with unmaterialized children was deleted. Because of this situation, we needed to make the relationship change objects more standalone, and change the infrastructure to use clientIds internally instead of expecting at least the child to be materialized. This change is somewhat destabilizing, and I realized that he don't have coverage of didSaveRecord(), but it's necessary. This change also makes several public methods on OneToManyChange, which is passed to the adapter, and requires that adapters acknowledge updates to the relationships, because of the possibility that a relationship change can need to be persisted even if the associated record is not loaded (i.e. the above deletion case).
Description Abstract: It turned out to be possible for a relationship change to exist even if no child record existed. This happened if a parent with unmaterialized children was deleted. Because of this situation, we needed to make the relationship change objects more standalone, and change the infrastructure to use clientIds internally instead of expecting at least the child to be materialized. This change is somewhat destabilizing, and I realized that he don't have coverage of didSaveRecord(), but it's necessary. This change also makes several public methods on OneToManyChange, which is passed to the adapter, and requires that adapters acknowledge updates to the relationships, because of the possibility that a relationship change can need to be persisted even if the associated record is not loaded (i.e. the above deletion case).

Description: In the REST adapter, only commit records that   are dirty due to an attribute change or because   a belongsTo relationship changed. Splits the adapter's commit() method into   an internal commit() and a public save()   method. Adds a fields property on the DS.Model class,   which returns an Ember.Map of both attributes   and relationships. Adds dirty reasons. This allows you to query   a model for more granularity than just whether   it is dirty or notyou can ask, for example,   if record.isDirtyBecause('attribute') to   determine if a record is dirty due to an   attribute being changed. Transactions now pass relationships into an   adapter's commit() method, in addition to   created, updated, and deleted records.
Description Abstract: In the REST adapter, only commit records that   are dirty due to an attribute change or because   a belongsTo relationship changed. Splits the adapter's commit() method into   an internal commit() and a public save()   method. Adds a fields property on the DS.Model class,   which returns an Ember.Map of both attributes   and relationships. Adds dirty reasons. This allows you to query   a model for more granularity than just whether   it is dirty or notyou can ask, for example,   if record.isDirtyBecause('attribute') to   determine if a record is dirty due to an   attribute being changed. Transactions now pass relationships into an   adapter's commit() method, in addition to   created, updated, and deleted records.

Description: Previously, concerns about how key names for given hashes returned from the server were spread across several different objects. Now, the serialization and materialization (converting an opaque data hash returned from the server into meaningful results for Ember Data) are handled by the DS.Serializer object. Instead of jamming this responsibility into the adapter, like so many clowns in a clown car, the adapter is now solely responsible for deciding which records should be committed, loading records, and notifying the store of changes in to record state.
Description Abstract: Previously, concerns about how key names for given hashes returned from the server were spread across several different objects. Now, the serialization and materialization (converting an opaque data hash returned from the server into meaningful results for Ember Data) are handled by the DS.Serializer object. Instead of jamming this responsibility into the adapter, like so many clowns in a clown car, the adapter is now solely responsible for deciding which records should be committed, loading records, and notifying the store of changes in to record state.

Message: WIP do more stuff in the adapter
Description: The most important change here is that filters now materialize records. This is necessary because the records no longer store their backing data as a serialized hash. The long-term perfz plan (for situations with huge numbers of data hashes) is to integrate with something like crossfilter to filter out unneeded records before loading into the store.
Message Abstract: WIP do more stuff in the adapter
Description Abstract: The most important change here is that filters now materialize records. This is necessary because the records no longer store their backing data as a serialized hash. The long-term perfz plan (for situations with huge numbers of data hashes) is to integrate with something like crossfilter to filter out unneeded records before loading into the store.

Message: WIP on moving relationships to adapter
Description: This commit is a work-in-progress on our work to separate out the semantics between dirty records and changes to their relationships. Highlights: 1) DS.Model#toJSON() now accepts more arguments to change how it serializes relationships 2) WIP on adapters being more active participants in deciding what records need to be committed 3) Changed belongsTo attributes no longer write ids to the record's data proxy 4) Records can be moved from the loaded.saved state to a new relationshipsInFlight state. This means that the record has changed relationships but not changed attributes that need to be persisted 5) Transaction now includes records that are not dirty but have changed relationships when calling an adapter's commit method (in the updated array of records)
Message Abstract: WIP on moving relationships to adapter
Description Abstract: This commit is a work-in-progress on our work to separate out the semantics between dirty records and changes to their relationships. Highlights: 1) DS.Model#toJSON() now accepts more arguments to change how it serializes relationships 2) WIP on adapters being more active participants in deciding what records need to be committed 3) Changed belongsTo attributes no longer write ids to the record's data proxy 4) Records can be moved from the loaded.saved state to a new relationshipsInFlight state. This means that the record has changed relationships but not changed attributes that need to be persisted 5) Transaction now includes records that are not dirty but have changed relationships when calling an adapter's commit method (in the updated array of records)

Message: In tests, replace async methods with sync versions
Description: This approach is an experimental attempt to allow tests to make assertions about the side-effects of asynchronous methods without having to explicitly declare a run loop using Ember.run. Now, any method that would trigger an autorun will instead wrap a run loop around its invocation (assuming that you have not already created a run loop). This means that if your async method makes other async calls downstack, those calls will still retain async behavior, but the top-level entry point will become synchronous.
Message Abstract: In tests, replace async methods with sync versions
Description Abstract: This approach is an experimental attempt to allow tests to make assertions about the side-effects of asynchronous methods without having to explicitly declare a run loop using Ember.run. Now, any method that would trigger an autorun will instead wrap a run loop around its invocation (assuming that you have not already created a run loop). This means that if your async method makes other async calls downstack, those calls will still retain async behavior, but the top-level entry point will become synchronous.

Message: Remove child dependency on parent when removed.
Description: If a record is added to a ManyArray, and the parent record of the ManyArray has not yet been assigned an ID, the child record is put into a pending state. The child does not leave the pending state until all of the records it depends on have been assigned an id. This commit resolves an issue where, if an object was removed from a ManyArray, it was still waiting (potentially indefinitely) for its parent record to be saved, even though there was no longer a dependency.
Message Abstract: Remove child dependency on parent when removed.
Description Abstract: If a record is added to a ManyArray, and the parent record of the ManyArray has not yet been assigned an ID, the child record is put into a pending state. The child does not leave the pending state until all of the records it depends on have been assigned an id. This commit resolves an issue where, if an object was removed from a ManyArray, it was still waiting (potentially indefinitely) for its parent record to be saved, even though there was no longer a dependency.

Message: Add hook to generate client-side IDs
Description: Previously, the store assumed that record IDs would always be generated on the server, and did not update bookkeeping information about server IDs until the didCreateRecord method was called. Now, adapters may optionally implement the generateIdForRecord method, which is invoked each time a new record is created. If this method exists, its return value will be used as the record's ID, and internal store bookkeeping will be updated. This commit also adds some cursory documentation to the DS.Adapter file.
Message Abstract: Add hook to generate client-side IDs
Description Abstract: Previously, the store assumed that record IDs would always be generated on the server, and did not update bookkeeping information about server IDs until the didCreateRecord method was called. Now, adapters may optionally implement the generateIdForRecord method, which is invoked each time a new record is created. If this method exists, its return value will be used as the record's ID, and internal store bookkeeping will be updated. This commit also adds some cursory documentation to the DS.Adapter file.

Description: Associations should respect namingConvention
Description Abstract: Associations should respect namingConvention

Message: Fixes bug when record is modified then deleted
Description: Because we defer updating record arrays to the end of the run loop, but we immediately remove records from record arrays if they are deleted, there existed a race condition where, if in the same run loop, a record was modified and then deleted. In that case, the record would be removed from the record array, but at the end of the run loop, it would be re-evaluated and potentially added back to filtered record arrays. This commit updates the test to take the deferred scheduling into account, and does not bother updating record arrays with records that have been deleted.
Message Abstract: Fixes bug when record is modified then deleted
Description Abstract: Because we defer updating record arrays to the end of the run loop, but we immediately remove records from record arrays if they are deleted, there existed a race condition where, if in the same run loop, a record was modified and then deleted. In that case, the record would be removed from the record array, but at the end of the run loop, it would be re-evaluated and potentially added back to filtered record arrays. This commit updates the test to take the deferred scheduling into account, and does not bother updating record arrays with records that have been deleted.

Message: Remove new deleted records from record arrays
Description: Fixes #168. Previously, only records that were sent to the adapter were being removed from record arrays. This is because the logic for removing them was in the deleted.start enter transition event, but new records that are deleted transition directly to the deleted.saved state (because deleting a new record is effectively a no-op; the adapter should never be notified about the record). As part of this change, we now have records that transition from created.uncommitted directly move themselves to their transaction's clean bucket (as they do not need to be sent to the adapter). This also fixes a bug where updated and uncommitted records were moving themselves to the clean bucket. Only newly created records should do this; updated records should move to the transaction's deleted bucket when deleted.
Message Abstract: Remove new deleted records from record arrays
Description Abstract: Fixes #168. Previously, only records that were sent to the adapter were being removed from record arrays. This is because the logic for removing them was in the deleted.start enter transition event, but new records that are deleted transition directly to the deleted.saved state (because deleting a new record is effectively a no-op; the adapter should never be notified about the record). As part of this change, we now have records that transition from created.uncommitted directly move themselves to their transaction's clean bucket (as they do not need to be sent to the adapter). This also fixes a bug where updated and uncommitted records were moving themselves to the clean bucket. Only newly created records should do this; updated records should move to the transaction's deleted bucket when deleted.

Description: Transactions now have a rollback() method that causes all of the records that belong to them to be reset to their state when they were first added to the transaction. The only exception to this is newly created states, which immediately become deleted upon transaction rollback.
Description Abstract: Transactions now have a rollback() method that causes all of the records that belong to them to be reset to their state when they were first added to the transaction. The only exception to this is newly created states, which immediately become deleted upon transaction rollback.

Message: Add intro documentation to DS.Model states
Message Abstract: Add intro documentation to DS.Model states

Description: Previously, there was some confusion internally about what was a record and what was a model. This commit makes the terminology consistent. A model is a schema definition that creates a subclass of DS.Model. Instances of those subclasses are called records. A record corresponds to a single entry in the persistence layer, as loaded by the adapter. To support this change, DS.ModelArray and its subclasses are now named DS.RecordArray. Since you should not be using these class names directly (but rather have them returned by store methods such as find() and filter()), this should not be a breaking API change and thus we have not updated the API revision number.
Description Abstract: Previously, there was some confusion internally about what was a record and what was a model. This commit makes the terminology consistent. A model is a schema definition that creates a subclass of DS.Model. Instances of those subclasses are called records. A record corresponds to a single entry in the persistence layer, as loaded by the adapter. To support this change, DS.ModelArray and its subclasses are now named DS.RecordArray. Since you should not be using these class names directly (but rather have them returned by store methods such as find() and filter()), this should not be a breaking API change and thus we have not updated the API revision number.

Description: This commit ensures that associations that were already materialized are properly updated if they were materialized while their parent record was still loading. Previously, this was managed by making the association computed property depend on data, but this would not cause any references to the association itself to be updated. This commit uses the fact that associations are ArrayProxys to update they content in place, thus updating any existing references as well.
Description Abstract: This commit ensures that associations that were already materialized are properly updated if they were materialized while their parent record was still loading. Previously, this was managed by making the association computed property depend on data, but this would not cause any references to the association itself to be updated. This commit uses the fact that associations are ArrayProxys to update they content in place, thus updating any existing references as well.

Message: Fix bug in attributes from previous commit
Description: We should always expect that values set on a record's attribute round-trip through the transform process at least once. For example, if I set the number 1 on a string attribute, I would expect that the next time I retrieve that attribute, it is the string "1". After that, however, subsequent gets should return objects with the same identity.
Message Abstract: Fix bug in attributes from previous commit
Description Abstract: We should always expect that values set on a record's attribute round-trip through the transform process at least once. For example, if I set the number 1 on a string attribute, I would expect that the next time I retrieve that attribute, it is the string "1". After that, however, subsequent gets should return objects with the same identity.

Description: Ember Data's policy about breaking changes is to follow semver versioning. However, as ember-data has not yet reached 1.0, semver allows to make breaking changes on any release. To avoid accumulating cruft from features that didn't make it into 1.0, we will increment a revision counter every time we introduce a breaking change, and raise an exception pointing the library user to BREAKING_CHANGES.md, which describes the breaking changes and how to update applications. See https://github.com/emberjs/data/blob/master/BREAKING_CHANGES.md for more details on the policy.
Description Abstract: Ember Data's policy about breaking changes is to follow semver versioning. However, as ember-data has not yet reached 1.0, semver allows to make breaking changes on any release. To avoid accumulating cruft from features that didn't make it into 1.0, we will increment a revision counter every time we introduce a breaking change, and raise an exception pointing the library user to BREAKING_CHANGES.md, which describes the breaking changes and how to update applications. See link for more details on the policy.

Message: Use DataProxy & toJSON instead of raw data hash
Description: Previously, a record's data was stored in a hash that was referenced by both the store and the record. Now that we have split the "canonical" source of data and the pending changes that have not yet been committed, we have created an internal DataProxy object that coalesces these two hashes into a transparent object that will return the correct value when asked. As part of this change, data semantically no longer means "the data hash to be sent to the server." In this case, you should use the toJSON() method.
Message Abstract: Use DataProxy & toJSON instead of raw data hash
Description Abstract: Previously, a record's data was stored in a hash that was referenced by both the store and the record. Now that we have split the "canonical" source of data and the pending changes that have not yet been committed, we have created an internal DataProxy object that coalesces these two hashes into a transparent object that will return the correct value when asked. As part of this change, data semantically no longer means "the data hash to be sent to the server." In this case, you should use the toJSON() method.

Message: Consolidate data modification to DataProxy object
Message Abstract: Consolidate data modification to DataProxy object

Description: This is so we can reclaim data for a data proxy that understands the changed hash (which we are about to rename unsavedData).
Description Abstract: This is so we can reclaim data for a data proxy that understands the changed hash (which we are about to rename unsavedData).

Message: Track canonical data and changes independently.
Description: Previously, changes to a record were stored   directly on the data hash. This meant that after   a change had been made, it was not possible to   determine the previous, "server truth" value. Now, a record has both a data hash and a   changes hash. This lays the groundwork for   transaction rollbacks, as well as saving the   foreign key on child records when they are added   or removed from a hasMany association. Now that data only holds server truth data and   not the changes, adapters should use the new   getJSON() method to determine what data should   be sent to the server. Updates the REST adapter to use getJSON() This commit also lays the groundwork for the   ability to do merges if a dirty record is   reloaded from the server.
Message Abstract: Track canonical data and changes independently.
Description Abstract: Previously, changes to a record were stored   directly on the data hash. This meant that after   a change had been made, it was not possible to   determine the previous, "server truth" value. Now, a record has both a data hash and a   changes hash. This lays the groundwork for   transaction rollbacks, as well as saving the   foreign key on child records when they are added   or removed from a hasMany association. Now that data only holds server truth data and   not the changes, adapters should use the new   getJSON() method to determine what data should   be sent to the server. Updates the REST adapter to use getJSON() This commit also lays the groundwork for the   ability to do merges if a dirty record is   reloaded from the server.

Message Abstract: Include list of breaking API changes

Description: When we bind to an error property in the view, it sets the value to undefined.  This causes the errors to not be an empty object, thus the model never transitions out of invalid. Also deleted our least prefered version of isEmptyObject, since having two did not seem necessary.
Description Abstract: When we bind to an error property in the view, it sets the value to undefined.  This causes the errors to not be an empty object, thus the model never transitions out of invalid. Also deleted our least prefered version of isEmptyObject, since having two did not seem necessary.

Message: Records move to default transaction after commit
Description: If a transaction is committed, the records that belong to it should be moved back to the default transaction. Additionally, if the default transaction is committed, those records should be moved to the new default transaction. Additionally, records should be able to be moved between transactions if they are still clean. Records can now be removed from transactions with the remove() method.
Message Abstract: Records move to default transaction after commit
Description Abstract: If a transaction is committed, the records that belong to it should be moved back to the default transaction. Additionally, if the default transaction is committed, those records should be moved to the new default transaction. Additionally, records should be able to be moved between transactions if they are still clean. Records can now be removed from transactions with the remove() method.

Description: This allows you to return a JSON response like: {     person: {       id: 1,       name: "Yehuda",       phone_numbers: [ 1 ]     },     phone_numbers: [       { id: 1, number: "555-5555" }     ]   } You can sideload data in any response. If the data has the same key as an association of the object being loaded or updated, ember-data will assume the type specified for that association. If you want to include unrelated data, you can specify a mapping property on your adapter: var adapter = DS.RESTAdapter.create({     mapping: {       summary: App.Summary     }   }); This will mean that any time ember-data sees an unexpected summary attribute on the response JSON, it will load the data as hashes for the App.Summary type.
Description Abstract: This allows you to return a JSON response like: {     person: {       id: 1,       name: "Yehuda",       phone_numbers: [ 1 ]     },     phone_numbers: [       { id: 1, number: "555-5555" }     ]   } You can sideload data in any response. If the data has the same key as an association of the object being loaded or updated, ember-data will assume the type specified for that association. If you want to include unrelated data, you can specify a mapping property on your adapter: var adapter = DS.RESTAdapter.create({     mapping: {       summary: App.Summary     }   }); This will mean that any time ember-data sees an unexpected summary attribute on the response JSON, it will load the data as hashes for the App.Summary type.

Message Abstract: Forbid changing transaction of dirty record
Description Abstract: We can make this work if there is a valid use-case, but conceptually changing a record's unit of work mid-stream seems wrong. If you want to create a record in a transaction, use transaction.createRecord(type).

Message: Reset the store's default transaction on commit
Description: When a store is committed, it should generate   a new transaction. Always explicitly specify a record's   transaction. This way a pending record can   belong to the default transaction, but won't   lose a reference to it when the store is   committed. Rename store's models property to   recordCache.
Message Abstract: Reset the store's default transaction on commit
Description Abstract: When a store is committed, it should generate   a new transaction. Always explicitly specify a record's   transaction. This way a pending record can   belong to the default transaction, but won't   lose a reference to it when the store is   committed. Rename store's models property to   recordCache.

Message: Don't share state instances between dirty states
Description: This bug was causing high WTFs/min. We were not consistent in using extend and create inside the DirtyState class, which meant that these two particular states would be shared between both updated and created, which lead to many _ bugs.

Description Abstract: This bug was causing high WTFs/min. We were not consistent in using extend and create inside the DirtyState class, which meant that these two particular states would be shared between both updated and created, which lead to many _ bugs.

Message: createRecord() should respect attribute key names
Description: Calling store.createRecord({ attr: 'foo' }) should respect keyName aliases defined in the attribute. Additionally, model arrays should not re-filter records until the run loop has finished, so that unnecessary work is not being done on intermediate state.

Description Abstract: Calling store.createRecord({ attr: 'foo' }) should respect keyName aliases defined in the attribute. Additionally, model arrays should not re-filter records until the run loop has finished, so that unnecessary work is not being done on intermediate state.
